Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Exploring the Emergence of Socialization in the Absence of a Shared Linguistic System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
University of California, San Diego doctoral candidate Sara Goico, supervised by Dr. John Haviland, will research how socialization emerges in the absence of a shared linguistic system. Linguistic anthropologists have long documented the importance of language in the socialization process. To further advance scientific understandings of the socialization process, the researcher explores how socialization can emerge in a context where a group of individuals do not have access to the language spoken by other members of their community. The researcher will investigate socialization among deaf children in Peru in inclusion classrooms, which is an appropriate site for such a project. In Peru, unlike the United States and many other countries, there is not an abundance hearing assistive technologies that allow socialization to emerge more rapidly; and Peruvian children do not have access to either a spoken or signed language. The socialization of these children will be observed through an entire year of inclusion education - the full-time placement of a deaf child in a regular education classroom of hearing students and teachers. This research is important to the field of language socialization because it will address two gaps in the current research - whether or not language is essential to membership in a community and how communicative resources other than spoken language are involved in the socialization process. The research will address the questions: 1. To what extent can individuals who do not have access to a shared and established language with the people around them become successful members of a community? 2. How does this process of socialization occur without a shared linguistic system? The researcher will spend 15 months in Peru following a small cohort of deaf students through their first year of inclusion education. The researcher will conduct participant observation, filming, and interviews in the inclusion classrooms and homes of a small group of deaf children. The analysis of this research will require generating detailed transcripts of video recorded classroom interactions between deaf students, their teachers, and peers.

This research project has the potential to make significant theoretical contributions to our understanding of human communication and sociality. Recently, researchers in linguistic anthropology have argued for a more accurate and nuanced understanding of the full range of human communication and the place of language within this broader framework. By focusing on individuals who do not have direct access to a linguistic system, this project will make a significant effort to bring a broad semiotic perspective to the field of language socialization. Furthermore, this research occurs at a time when inclusion education is spreading rapidly around the globe, but research on the effects of these educational programs lags behind. This research has far-reaching potential to better understand the system of inclusion education for the deaf and to influence the policies and implementation of this educational system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Iquitos, Peru is a city of 500,000 in the heart of the Peruvian Amazon. The majority of deaf children in Iquitos have not had access to a conventional language, either spoken or signed. Those deaf children who are currently in the education system attend regular education schools with all-hearing classmates and teachers, a policy known in Peru as inclusion education. Surprisingly, even without the ability to participate in the classroom language, many of these students appear to be integrated members of their classroom communities. This research project probes the extent to which it is possible to be a member of a community without sharing the community language and how the process of language socialization occurs without a linguistic system.

 

Deaf individuals who grow up without access to a conventional language often invent idiosyncratic gesture systems known as homesigns. This research project analyzed the gesture systems of ten deaf homesigners in regular education schools in and around Iquitos. These deaf students exhibited remarkable diversity in their homesign systems, especially in the level of expressivity and the extent to which information is carried primarily on the hands or on the whole body. This unique opportunity to observe human communication without a conventional linguistic system demonstrates the range of human communicative creativity and the many ways in which semiotic resources other than linguistic signs are utilized in meaning creation. Moreover, the opportunity to witness such diversity, also allows for comparisons across this population for common communicative practices shared by all. While this is only a small sample size, such comparisons can provide evidence for future research on the universal ways in which humans capitalize on the manual communicative resources at their disposal.

 

This research also adds to the literature on language socialization by highlighting community reactions to linguistically marginal individuals. The inclusion classrooms in this sample provide evidence of how hearing peers and teachers accommodate the deaf student in order to conceal his or her linguistically marginal status, even if it is to the detriment of the deaf student’s academic achievement. While not available in the current research sample, Co-PI Goico heard of a number of specific examples, where deaf students were bullied and ostracized due to their marginal status. This research provides the opportunity to analyze the effects of inclusion and exclusion with linguistically marginal populations, a topic which is of significant interest in today’s increasingly multilingual school system.

 

Research, such as this project, also contributes to determining the effects of current international special education policies with regard to deaf students. Due to the fact that 90-95% of deaf children are born to hearing families, one of the few places deaf individuals gain access to a sign language is at school. Nevertheless, children with disabilities in the developing world are one of the largest populations without access to education. In the case of deafness, this has far reaching effects. Recent research indicates that language deprivation into adolescence may result in cognitive and communicate deficits, even after a language is acquired. Efforts, such as Education for All and inclusion education for special needs populations, are seeking to change this situation. The current study, however, provides a harsh critique of the practice of educating deaf children in regular education schools with insufficient economic and human resources. In Iquitos, the inclusion school is not a place where deaf children are exposed to a sign language or other deaf individuals.
